bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Thomas Corbin, 1708 September 25

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Thomas Corbin, September 25, 1708, that he no longer has any connection with the affairs of the estate of Ralph Wormeley because they now manage their own properties and he will no longer write to Corbin about affairs of the estate.

div1.head: Robert Carter to Thomas Corbin, [September 25, 1708]

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
[September 25, 1708]
Mr Tho Corbin

div1.p:
I have done Concerning my Self with Young Wormeleys affairs, their Estate is e[ntire]
ly under their own Govermt. & indeed `tis time they addict themselves to business & so I take
my leave of it & You too from any further writing to You on their Accot: remaining
Yor affectiont Countryman &
humble Servant

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783, and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 179. Extract printed William and Mary Quarterly, 1st. ser., 17(1909): 264.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return addres, county, and colony have been added to this unheaded letter.
[1] This letter precedes another of this date in the letter book on the same theme.

[2] Carter often referred to in their youth as his "Cozns." Ralph Wormeley (ca. 1681-1714), Ralph Wormeley's (d.1701) oldest son; and John Wormeley (1689-1727) because their parents were his brother- and sister-in- law. He was one of the boys' trustees under their father's will.
